Hands-on Exercise 11

Published

October 27, 2024

Modified

November 2, 2024

Overview

Geographically weighted regression (GWR) is a spatial statistical technique that takes non-stationary variables into consideration (e.g., climate; demographic factors; physical environment characteristics) and models the local relationships between these independent variables and an outcome of interest (also known as dependent variable). In this hands-on exercise, you will learn how to build hedonic pricing models by using GWR methods. The dependent variable is the resale prices of condominium in 2015. The independent variables are divided into either structural and locational.

The Data

Two data sets will be used in this model building exercise, they are:

  • URA Master Plan subzone boundary in shapefile format (i.e. MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL)

  • condo_resale_2015 in csv format (i.e. condo_resale_2015.csv)

Loading the Data

The code chunks below installs and launches the necessary R packages into R environment.

pacman::p_load(olsrr, corrplot, ggpubr, sf, spdep, GWmodel, tmap, tidyverse, gtsummary, ggstatsplot, performance)
condo_resale <- read_csv("data/aspatial/Condo_resale_2015.csv")

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
mpsz <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `/Users/jezelei/jezeleii/IS415-GA/In-Class_Exercise/InClassEx11/data/geospatial'

condo_resale_sf <- st_as_sf(condo_resale,
                            coords = c("LONGITUDE", "LATITUDE"),
                            crs=4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs=3414)

Correlation Analysis

ggcorrmat(condo_resale[, 5:23])

Building a Hedonic Pricing Model using Multiple Linear Regression Method

condo_mlr <- lm(formula = SELLING_PRICE ~ AREA_SQM + AGE  + 
                        PROX_CBD + PROX_CHILDCARE + PROX_ELDERLYCARE    + 
                        PROX_URA_GROWTH_AREA + PROX_MRT + PROX_PARK + 
                        PROX_PRIMARY_SCH + PROX_TOP_PRIMARY_SCH + PROX_SHOPPING_MALL   +
                        PROX_BUS_STOP + PROX_SUPERMARKET + 
                        NO_Of_UNITS + FAMILY_FRIENDLY +
                        FREEHOLD + LEASEHOLD_99YR, 
                data= condo_resale_sf)

summary(condo_mlr)

Call:

Variable Selection

condo_fw_mlr <- ols_step_forward_p(
  condo_mlr, 
  p_val = 0.05, 
  details= FALSE)

Any independent variable we add in, it will compare the variable at every iteration.

Building Backward Stepwise MLR

condo_bw_mlr <- ols_step_backward_p(
  condo_mlr, 
  p_val = 0.05, 
  details= FALSE) 
condo_bw_mlr

Building Stepwise Multiple Linear Regression

condo_sb_mlr <- ols_step_both_p(
  condo_mlr, 
  p_val = 0.05, 
  details= FALSE) 
condo_sb_mlr

Model Selection

metric <- compare_performance(condo_mlr, 
                              condo_fw_mlr$model, 
                              condo_bw_mlr$model, 
                              condo_sb_mlr$model)
Some of the nested models seem to be identical
metric$Name <- gsub(".*\\\\[a-zA-Z0-9_]+\\\\,\\\\model\\\\.*","\\1", metric$Name)
#plot(metric)

Checking for Multicollinearity

check_collinearity(condo_sb_mlr$model)
# Check for Multicollinearity
